e4: I recommended rejecting the new policy because it might not be well-received by the market and cause stocks to drop. Additionally, many investors have gotten used to accounting earnings minus a $0.50 correction so they'll probably keep doing that as long people's thinking goes, leading in potential short-term instability around what stock valuation will ultimately turn out after full market exposure.  Meanwhile, it makes for smoother corporate governance under existing rules.
e5: In my view, an ethical reporting policy should be transparent and accurate in its presentation of financial data. A good policy also treats all stakeholders fairly and avoids any practices that could lead to misinformation or market confusion. In the context of publicly traded companies like ABC, consider the interests of both sophisticated investors with deep knowledge of company operations and retail investors who might not fully understand the nuances at play. An ethics reporting policy for a public holding should account for the needs, understanding , and fairness to each segment.
e6: Yes. Some potential follow-up questions that might address my lack of enthusiasm with changing reporting policy could be What do we have implemented our current practice without clear public education strategies; What does it take to effectively update investors' knowledge around changes made ? Is this possible and would there be any extra cost we incur.
